liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In April of this year, former Liberal Minister Ken Wyatt split with the Coalition after Opposition leader Peter Dutton announced the party's decision to support the "No" vote. Speaking to RN's Patricia Karvelas Mr Wyatt said he was "disappointed" with the Mr Dutton's behavior in the lead up to the referendum. "I’m disappointed because Peter was part of the process, he had access to the information and he never had a serious discussion with me on the voice," he said. The arguments that he’s putting forward are not factual, they’re contentious in order to create fear and division and they are intentional in order to sink the voice." Mr Wyatt agreed that much of the Liberal party's Voice messaging is 'Trumpian'. "Some of the tactics are copybook out of America. The fake news, the statements of ‘You’ll end up paying Aboriginal people’, ‘You’ll lose land’, ‘You won’t be able to do this’. That concerns me," Mr Wyatt said. Listen to the full interview below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'Tactics are copybook out of America': Ken Wyatt on the Liberal Voice strategy

featuredLink.title: 'Tactics are copybook out of America': Ken Wyatt on the Liberal Voice strategy - ABC listen

children.content: Key Wyatt left the Liberal party in April 2023
(ABC News: Andrew O'Connor)
In April of this year,
former Liberal Minister Ken Wyatt
split with the Coalition after
Opposition leader Peter Dutton
announced the party's decision to support the "No" vote.
Speaking to
RN's Patricia Karvelas
Mr Wyatt said he was "disappointed" with the Mr Dutton's behavior in the lead up to the referendum.
"I’m disappointed because Peter was part of the process, he had access to the information and he never had a serious discussion with me on the voice," he said.
The arguments that he’s putting forward are not factual, they’re contentious in order to create fear and division and they are intentional in order to sink the voice."
Mr Wyatt agreed that much of the Liberal party's Voice messaging is 'Trumpian'.

"Some of the tactics are copybook out of America. The fake news, the statements of ‘You’ll end up paying Aboriginal people’, ‘You’ll lose land’, ‘You won’t be able to do this’. That concerns me," Mr Wyatt said.
Listen to the full interview below.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese continues his referendum eve tour with a speech in Adelaide Central Markets. "We have an opportunity for Australians to do better. To do better to show respect for the first Australians, but to do something for ourselves, as well, because we will feel better. We will feel better about ourselves on Sunday with a Yes vote." The Prime Minister is hitting a lot of the same talking points this morning about how the Voice won't affect 97 per cent of Australians and a request for people to show "kindness" at the polls tomorrow. " Kindness costs nothing. Thinking of others costs nothing. This is a time where Australians have that opportunity to show the generosity of spirit that I see in the Australian character where at the worst of times we always see the best of the Australian character."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 'We will feel better about ourselves on Sunday with a Yes vote', Albanese says

children.content: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese at Adelaide Central Markets.
(ABC News: Brant Cumming)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese
continues his referendum eve tour with a speech in Adelaide Central Markets.

"We have an opportunity for Australians to do better. To do better to show respect for the first Australians, but to do something for ourselves, as well, because we will feel better. We will feel better about ourselves on Sunday with a Yes vote."

The Prime Minister is hitting a lot of the same talking points this morning about how the Voice won't affect 97 per cent of Australians and a request for people to show "kindness" at the polls tomorrow.

Kindness costs nothing. Thinking of others costs nothing. This is a time where Australians have that opportunity to show the generosity of spirit that I see in the Australian character where at the worst of times we always see the best of the Australian character."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Posting a photo of his completed ballot paper to X (formerly Twitter) late last week, one No voter may have had regrets after other users responded that he may have invalidated his vote. In a post implying that Australia's secret ballot system could be rorted, the user shared an image showing he had identified himself on his ballot paper by writing: "[Name redacted] voted 'no'. I am [name redacted]." But others should not follow his lead if they wish for their vote to be counted. As fellow X users quickly pointed out, guidelines published by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) suggest the man's vote would likely be counted as informal by polling officials. "If, in the opinion of the DRO (Divisional Returning Officer), there is sufficient writing on the ballot paper to uniquely identify the voter, the ballot paper is informal," the AEC guidelines state. Read more about the biggest debunked claims of the referendum below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Why you shouldn't write your name on your referendum ballot paper

featuredLink.title: Don't do this to your ballot paper if you want your vote to count in the referendum

children.content: Posting a photo of his completed ballot paper to X (formerly Twitter) late last week,
one No voter
may have had regrets after other users responded that he may have invalidated his vote.
In a post implying that Australia's secret ballot system could be rorted, the user shared an image showing he had identified himself on his ballot paper by writing:
"[Name redacted] voted 'no'. I am [name redacted]."
But others should not follow his lead if they wish for their vote to be counted.
As fellow X users quickly pointed out,
guidelines
published by the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) suggest the man's vote would likely be counted as informal by polling officials.
"If, in the opinion of the DRO (Divisional Returning Officer), there is sufficient writing on the ballot paper to uniquely identify the voter, the ballot paper is informal," the AEC guidelines state.
Read more about the biggest debunked claims of the referendum below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Minister for Foreign Affairs, Penny Wong, urges Australians in Israel to get on the repatriation flights, starting today. "I would urge anyone who wishes to leave, to not delay," she says. She also says Australia is engaging with Egypt and the US about seeking to establish humanitarian corridors, "but obviously the situation on the ground is extremely difficult". Ms Wong also stressed the importance of "calm leadership" and bringing Australians together, rather than create division. "It is time for all of us to say we stand against all hatred, all prejudice. There is no place for anti-Semitism, as there is no place for discrimination and prejudice of any kind. It is a time for us to come together. "We know this is distressing for the Jewish community. We know there are many in Australia who have very strong views about the Palestinian aspirations and I would say this — one of the great tragedies, apart from the horrific nature of Hamas' actions, one of the great tragedies of what they have done is they have pushed further away the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australia, Egypt and US seeking to establish humanitarian corridors, says Penny Wong

props.alt: An image of Penny Wong speaking at a press conference. Behind her is Anthony Albanese.

children.content: (ABC News)
Minister for Foreign Affairs, Penny Wong, urges Australians in Israel to get on the repatriation flights, starting today.
"I would urge anyone who wishes to leave, to not delay," she says.
She also says Australia is engaging with Egypt and the US about seeking to establish humanitarian corridors, "but obviously the situation on the ground is extremely difficult".
Ms Wong also stressed the importance of "calm leadership" and bringing Australians together, rather than create division.

"It is time for all of us to say we stand against all hatred, all prejudice. There is no place for anti-Semitism, as there is no place for discrimination and prejudice of any kind. It is a time for us to come together.

"We know this is distressing for the Jewish community. We know there are many in Australia who have very strong views about the Palestinian aspirations and I would say this — one of the great tragedies, apart from the horrific nature of Hamas' actions, one of the great tragedies of what they have done is they have pushed further away the legitimate aspirations of the Palestinian people."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Iranian Minister of Foreign Affairs Hossein Amirabdollahian says that if Israel's bombardment of Gaza continues, the war may open on "other fronts," an apparent reference to the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah. "In light of the continued aggression, war crimes, and siege on Gaza, opening other fronts is a real possibility," Amirabdollahian said, speaking to journalists on his arrival in Beirut late on Thursday. Early Thursday, Amirabdollahian had visited Iraq, where he made similar statements after a meeting with Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani. Questions have swirled around the extent of Iran's role in the unprecedented surprise attack launched by the Palestinian militant group Hamas on Israel on Saturday. Hamas officials have denied that Iran was directly involved in planning the attack or green-lighted it, and to date no government worldwide has offered direct evidence that Iran orchestrated the attack. However, many have pointed to Iran's long sponsorship of Hamas that has included training, funding and providing it with weapons. Associated Press
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: If Israel doesn't end attacks, war may open on 'other fronts', Iran says

props.alt: A man in a suit sits and glances sideways, while sitting in front of the Iranian flag

children.content: (Reuters: Issei Kato)

Iranian Minister of Foreign Affairs Hossein Amirabdollahian says that if Israel's bombardment of Gaza continues, the war may open on "other fronts," an apparent reference to the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah.

"In light of the continued aggression, war crimes, and siege on Gaza, opening other fronts is a real possibility," Amirabdollahian said, speaking to journalists on his arrival in Beirut late on Thursday.
Early Thursday, Amirabdollahian had visited Iraq, where he made similar statements after a meeting with Prime Minister Mohammed Shia al-Sudani.
Questions have swirled around the extent of Iran's role in the unprecedented surprise attack launched by the Palestinian militant group Hamas on Israel on Saturday.

Hamas officials have denied that Iran was directly involved in planning the attack or green-lighted it, and to date no government worldwide has offered direct evidence that Iran orchestrated the attack.
However, many have pointed to Iran's long sponsorship of Hamas that has included training, funding and providing it with weapons.
Associated Press

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says 19 Australians have reigstered themselves as trying to flee Gaza. "There is a family, for example, from Adelaide, of four, and we are having discussions with the Egyptian government about the potential to get them out into Egypt through that southern border," he tells ABC News Breakfast. "It's closed, of course, at the moment, formally, but we are having discussions to try to ensure that Australians can be gotten to safety. "We want all Australians to be safe in the region and be able to leave, whether they're in Israel or Gaza." The PM says 1,600 Australians are registered as being in the region of Israel, Gaza or the West Bank, but not all of them are necessarily trying to get out. You can read more here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: PM says 19 Australians are trying to flee Gaza

featuredLink.title: Adelaide family of four among 19 Australians trying to leave Gaza

props.alt: Anthony Albanese in a suit and tie giving a TV interview outdoors near a jetty on the ocean

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says 19 Australians have reigstered themselves as trying to flee Gaza.

"There is a family, for example, from Adelaide, of four, and we are having discussions with the Egyptian government about the potential to get them out into Egypt through that southern border," he tells ABC News Breakfast.
"It's closed, of course, at the moment, formally, but we are having discussions to try to ensure that Australians can be gotten to safety.
"We want all Australians to be safe in the region and be able to leave, whether they're in Israel or Gaza."
The PM says 1,600 Australians are registered as being in the region of Israel, Gaza or the West Bank, but not all of them are necessarily trying to get out.
You can read more here:
